query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Tal era io in quella turba spessa, 11 volgendo a loro, e qua e là, la faccia, 12 e promettendo mi sciogliea da essa.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Such was I in that dense crowd, 11 turning my face to them, here and there, 12 and promising myself to free myself from it.
**Cornish:**
10 Henwys oen oen oen yn an wonvos spessa, 11 ow trohe dhethow, ena ha henna, an fas, 12 ha ow promettan ow thueth dheworth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Quiv’ era l’Aretin che da le braccia 14 fiere di Ghin di Tacco ebbe la morte, 15 e l’altro ch’annegò correndo in caccia.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Here was the Aretine who from the fierce arms 14 of Ghin di Tacco met his death, 15 and the other who drowned while running in pursuit.
**Cornish:**
13 Ama oen an Aretin a-dhyworth bregh 14 Ghin di Tacco y fethas y vernans, 15 ha'n aral a veu boghes ow resek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Quivi pregava con le mani sporte 17 Federigo Novello, e quel da Pisa 18 che fé parer lo buon Marzucco forte.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Here prayed with outstretched hands 17 Federigo Novello, and the one from Pisa 18 who made the good Marzucco seem strong.
**Cornish:**
16 Ama oen Federigo Novello a bedha gans an dhewolgorrys, 17 ha'n hini a-dhyworth Pisa 18 a wrug Marzucco da ynjyn sevel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Come libero fui da tutte quante 26 quell’ ombre che pregar pur ch’altri prieghi, 27 sì che s’avacci lor divenir sante,
28 io cominciai: «El par che tu mi nieghi, 29 o luce mia, espresso in alcun testo 30 che decreto del cielo orazion pieghi;
31 e questa gente prega pur di questo: 32 sarebbe dunque loro speme vana, 33 o non m’è ’l detto tuo ben manifesto?».
query.result:
**English:**
25 When I was free from all those 26 shades who prayed only that others might pray, 27 so that they might hasten to become holy,
28 I began: "It seems that you deny me, 29 O my light, expressed in some text 30 that a decree of heaven bends a pious prayer;
31 and these people pray only for this: 32 would their hope then be in vain, 33 or is your saying not clear to me?".
**Cornish:**
25 Pythegyll ow free ow thueth dhyworth oll an re 26 an enevalow henna a bedha pur rag aral a bedho, 27 marnas bythkweth ow hasti dhethow dhe ves sans,
28 Me a dhallathas: "Yth par dheth owth om nagha, 29 O'm golon, ow leverys yn nebes tekst 30 marnas dekret a'n nev a dro dhe ves pedn pious;
31 ha'n dus ma a bedh pur rag hemma: 32 a vo dhethow aga spyrans yn van, 33 po nyns yw'th leverel dhe'm ow kler dhe ves?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Veramente a così alto sospetto 44 non ti fermar, se quella nol ti dice 45 che lume fia tra ’l vero e lo ’ntelletto.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Truly, at such a high suspicion 44 do not stop, if she does not tell you 45 who will be the light between the truth and the intellect.
**Cornish:**
43 Yn wir, dhe sospeth mar uhel, 44 na wra fetha, marnas henna nyns ow leverel dhe'th, 45 neb a vo golon ynter an wir ha'n intellet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Non so se ’ntendi: io dico di Beatrice; 47 tu la vedrai di sopra, in su la vetta 48 di questo monte, ridere e felice».
query.result:
**English:**
46 I do not know if you understand: I speak of Beatrice; 47 you will see her above, on the summit 48 of this mountain, laughing and happy.
**Cornish:**
46 Me nyns ow tos marnas owth om komprehendya: Me a leverel a-dro dhe Vesek; 47 Ty a wra'y gweles ena a-ugh, warbarth an kres 48 a'n menydh ma, ow hwerthin ha lowen.".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 E io: «Segnore, andiamo a maggior fretta, 50 ché già non m’affatico come dianzi, 51 e vedi omai che ’l poggio l’ombra getta».
query.result:
**English:**
49 And I: "Sir, let us go with greater haste, 50 for I am not as weary as before, 51 and you see now that the hill casts its shadow".
**Cornish:**
49 Ha me: "Syr, gans moy fretta gansowgh, 50 rag nyns yw ow fatigya mar ugens, 51 ha ty a wel yth omma an menydh ow tos ow skwydh.".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 «Noi anderem con questo giorno innanzi», 53 rispuose, «quanto più potremo omai; 54 ma ’l fatto è d’altra forma che non stanzi.
query.result:
**English:**
52 "We will go forward with this day ahead of us," 53 he replied, "as much as we can now; 54 but the fact is different from what you think.
**Cornish:**
52 "Ny agan mos ha bos an jornama ma," 53 ev a leveris, "kemmys a allawnyth nyns; 54 mes an gwir a wra dalleth ages an jesta."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Prima che sie là sù, tornar vedrai 56 colui che già si cuopre de la costa, 57 sì che ’ suoi raggi tu romper non fai.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Before you are up there, you will see again 56 the one who is already covering himself with the hillside, 57 so that you do not break his rays.
**Cornish:**
55 Kyns ages allá, why a welow 56 an hini a wra dalleth ow kul an menydh, 57 marnas ow thurov y gila na wra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Ma vedi là un’anima che, posta 59 sola soletta, inverso noi riguarda: 60 quella ne ’nsegnerà la via più tosta».
query.result:
**English:**
58 But see there a soul who, placed 59 all alone, is looking towards us: 60 she will show us the quickest way.
**Cornish:**
58 Mes gweles allá un eneval a, settys 59 onan onan, ow tos ow tos orthyn: 60 henna a dhysky dhe'n fordh an moyha byghan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Venimmo a lei: o anima lombarda, 62 come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa 63 e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda!
64 Ella non ci dicëa alcuna cosa, 65 ma lasciavane gir, solo sguardando 66 a guisa di leon quando si posa.
query.result:
**English:**
61 We came to her: oh Lombard soul, 62 how proud and disdainful you were 63 and in the movement of your eyes, honest and slow!
64 She did not say anything to us, 65 but let us go, only looking 66 like a lion when it rests.
**Cornish:**
61 Ny dheuthsa dhodhi: o eneval Lombardek, 62 pyth ostyth ow sevel orth ha disdeynus 63 ha'gas movyans dhewlagow onest ha lent!
64 Hi na leveris dimp tra veth, 65 mes hi a'gan lellis mos, ow selwel yn unnik 66 kepar lew pan yw ewn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Pur Virgilio si trasse a lei, pregando 68 che ne mostrasse la miglior salita; 69 e quella non rispuose al suo dimando,
70 ma di nostro paese e de la vita 71 ci ’nchiese; e ’l dolce duca incominciava 72 «Mantüa . . . », e l’ombra, tutta in sé romita,
73 surse ver’ lui del loco ove pria stava, 74 dicendo: «O Mantoano, io son Sordello 75 de la tua terra!»; e l’un l’altro abbracciava.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Yet Virgil drew himself to her, praying 68 that she would show us the best way up; 69 and she did not answer his request,
70 but asked us about our country and our life; 71 and the gentle leader began 72 "Mantua . . . ", and the shade, all withdrawn in itself,
73 rose towards him from the place where it was standing before, 74 saying: "O Mantuan, I am Sordello 75 from your land!"; and they embraced each other.
**Cornish:**
67 Mes Virgili a'gan lellis dhodhi, ow pedas 68 dasi dhe dhiskwedhes an wella bos dhe'n drehedhes; 69 ha henna na leveris dym dhe vynnos,
70 mes hi a vynnis dimp tra'gan pow ha'gan byw 71 ha'gan myghtern melyon a gommensya 72 "Mantua . . . ", ha'gan sketh, oll onan dhe hunan,
73 a sevis dhe'n fordh dhe'n le mayth ostyth, 74 ow leverel: "O Mantoanek, my a wra Sordello 75 a'ga pow!" ha i a'gan golghi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Ahi serva Italia, di dolore ostello, 77 nave sanza nocchiere in gran tempesta, 78 non donna di province, ma bordello!
79 Quell’ anima gentil fu così presta, 80 sol per lo dolce suon de la sua terra, 81 di fare al cittadin suo quivi festa;
82 e ora in te non stanno sanza guerra 83 li vivi tuoi, e l’un l’altro si rode 84 di quei ch’un muro e una fossa serra.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Alas, servant Italy, hostel of sorrow, 77 ship without a helmsman in a great storm, 78 not a lady of provinces, but a brothel!
79 That gentle soul was so quick, 80 just for the sweet sound of his land, 81 to make a feast for his fellow citizen here;
82 and now in you your living do not live without war, 83 and they gnaw at each other, 84 those whom one wall and one moat enclose.
**Cornish:**
76 Ah, servus Itali, osteli a'n dolor, 77 bagas heb steryades yn an tempest meur, 78 nyns benenes a brovinsow, mes bordello!
79 An eneval melyon ostyth kemmys prest, 80 oll rag an dowr melyon a'y pow, 81 dhe gul gul dym y gyvythkador yma;
82 ha lemmyn nyns yw ow sevel heb bresel 83 ow byw, ha i a'gan golghi, 84 an re a wra unn wal ha unn foss ow serri.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Cerca, misera, intorno da le prode 86 le tue marine, e poi ti guarda in seno, 87 s’alcuna parte in te di pace gode.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Look, wretch, around your shores 86 and then look within yourself, 87 if any part of you enjoys peace.
**Cornish:**
85 Sel, meskin, a-dro dhe'n fordhow 86 dhew vorvaow, ha wosa dhe hunan, 87 mar yw unn rann a-dhi ow kesunya peth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Che val perché ti racconciasse il freno 89 Iustinïano, se la sella è vòta? 90 Sanz’ esso fora la vergogna meno.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Why should Justinian mend your bridle 89 if the saddle is empty? 90 Without it, the shame would be less.
**Cornish:**
88 Pandra vyth Iustinïan dhe gul gul dhyw freno 89 mar yw an sella gwag? 90 Heb henna, an gwarth a vydh le.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Ahi gente che dovresti esser devota, 92 e lasciar seder Cesare in la sella, 93 se bene intendi ciò che Dio ti nota,
94 guarda come esta fiera è fatta fella 95 per non esser corretta da li sproni, 96 poi che ponesti mano a la predella.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Ah, people who should be devout, 92 and let Caesar sit in the saddle, 93 if you understand well what God notes about you,
94 see how this beast has become wicked 95 for not being corrected by the spurs, 96 since you put your hand to the stirrup.
**Cornish:**
91 Ah, pobel a dhalleth bos dhevot, 92 ha lell Caesar dhe ewn yn an sella, 93 mar t'eus komprehendya daffar a nota Duw,
94 sel pyth yw an best magh kemmys fella 95 rag na vos корректировансa gans an sproni, 96 wosa dhe dhaskerghes dhew an predella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 O Alberto tedesco ch’abbandoni 98 costei ch’è fatta indomita e selvaggia, 99 e dovresti inforcar li suoi arcioni,
100 giusto giudicio da le stelle caggia 101 sovra ’l tuo sangue, e sia novo e aperto, 102 tal che ’l tuo successor temenza n’aggia!
103 Ch’avete tu e ’l tuo padre sofferto, 104 per cupidigia di costà distretti, 105 che ’l giardin de lo ’mperio sia diserto.
query.result:
**English:**
97 O German Albert who abandon 98 this one who has become untamed and savage, 99 and you should mount her saddlebow,
100 may just judgement fall from the stars 101 upon your blood, and may it be new and open, 102 so that your successor may fear it!
103 For what have you and your father suffered, 104 constrained by greed for this side, 105 that the garden of the empire should be deserted.
**Cornish:**
97 O Albert Almayn a wra ow thue 98 henna yw kemmys indomita ha gwyls, 99 ha dhalleth bos dhe ewn warbarth y arconi,
100 just judgement a wra ow kwetha a'n sterri 101 warbarth dhew dhew gwydh, ha bos nowydh ha apert, 102 marnas dhew dhew ollower a wra ow aga!
103 Rag pyth owth ha dhew das a wra ow soffer, 104 rag cupidigia rag an pow ma, 105 marnas an jardi a'n emper a wra disert.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Vieni a veder Montecchi e Cappelletti, 107 Monaldi e Filippeschi, uom sanza cura: 108 color già tristi, e questi con sospetti!
109 Vien, crudel, vieni, e vedi la pressura 110 d’i tuoi gentili, e cura lor magagne; 111 e vedrai Santafior com’ è oscura!
112 Vieni a veder la tua Roma che piagne 113 vedova e sola, e dì e notte chiama: 114 «Cesare mio, perché non m’accompagne?».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Come and see the Montagues and Capulets, 107 Monaldi and Filippeschi, men without care: 108 those already sad, and these suspicious!
109 Come, cruel one, come and see the oppression 110 of your nobles, and heal their suffering; 111 and you will see how dark Santafior is!
112 Come and see your Rome that weeps, 113 widowed and alone, and calls out day and night: 114 "My Caesar, why do you not accompany me?".
**Cornish:**
106 DeuwhwelwelMontekkihaKapellet, 107 Monaldi ha Filippeski, gwryvyth heb goweth: 108 liw trist deudh, ha'n re ma dowt!
109 Deuwhwel, breus, deuwhwel, ha gweles an golgh, 110 a'th wynn, ha gwella aga klav, 111 ha gweles pyth yw Santafior tewl!
112 Deuwhwel weles Roma agas ow weli, 113 wedoow ha onan, ow kewsel dydh ha nos: 114 "Kesar vy, peragis na'm kever?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Vieni a veder la gente quanto s’ama! 116 e se nulla di noi pietà ti move, 117 a vergognar ti vien de la tua fama.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Come and see how much people love each other! 116 And if nothing of us moves you to pity, 117 come to be ashamed of your reputation.
**Cornish:**
115 Deuwhwel weles an bobel pyth yw aga karanteth! 116 Ha nag yw tra a ni owth a'th teves, 117 deuwhwel dhe wrussa a'th brys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 E se licito m’è, o sommo Giove 119 che fosti in terra per noi crucifisso, 120 son li giusti occhi tuoi rivolti altrove?
121 O è preparazion che ne l’abisso 122 del tuo consiglio fai per alcun bene 123 in tutto de l’accorger nostro scisso?
124 Ché le città d’Italia tutte piene 125 son di tiranni, e un Marcel diventa 126 ogne villan che parteggiando viene.
query.result:
**English:**
118 And if it is permissible for me, O supreme Jove, 119 who were crucified on earth for us, 120 are your just eyes turned elsewhere?
121 Or is it a preparation that in the abyss 122 of your counsel you make for some good, 123 completely hidden from our understanding?
124 For all the cities of Italy are full 125 of tyrants, and every peasant who joins a faction 126 becomes a new Marcel.
**Cornish:**
118 Ha mar yw possybyl dhe'm, o Jow Kres, 119 a veu yn-tir rag ni war groesyes, 120 yw dha lygaow just ow tos ow treylyes?
121 Po yw paratowr yn-dann an dibyn 122 a'th gonsel rag nebes da 123 ow tos ow komprehendya ni?
124 Rag an oll sita yn Itali yw leun 125 gans tirannoryon, ha pub treusour 126 a wra'n tirann pan wra parti.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Fiorenza mia, ben puoi esser contenta 128 di questa digression che non ti tocca, 129 mercé del popol tuo che si argomenta.
query.result:
**English:**
127 My Florence, you can be content 128 with this digression that does not concern you, 129 thanks to your people who are striving.
**Cornish:**
127 Firenze vy, yth yw possybyl bos sodhek 128 gans an digresyon ma na'th kevrenn, 129 dres an bobel agas owth yw strivya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Molti han giustizia in cuore, e tardi scocca 131 per non venir sanza consiglio a l’arco; 132 ma il popol tuo l’ha in sommo de la bocca.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Many have justice in their hearts, but it is slow to be released, 131 so as not to come to the bow without counsel; 132 but your people have it on the tip of their tongues.
**Cornish:**
130 Lies yw lies a-ji yn aga kolonnow, mes lent yw dhe skwydya 131 rag na dheuth dhe'n bow heb konsel; 132 mes an bobel agas yw aga gorra yn aga genevow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Molti rifiutan lo comune incarco; 134 ma il popol tuo solicito risponde 135 sanza chiamare, e grida: «I’ mi sobbarco!».
query.result:
**English:**
133 Many refuse the common burden; 134 but your people respond eagerly 135 without being called, and cry out: "I take it upon myself!".
**Cornish:**
133 Lies yw lies owth a wra'n an garg vynres; 134 mes an bobel agas owth yw owth leverel 135 heb galow, ha kewsel: "My a wra'n an garg!".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Or ti fa lieta, ché tu hai ben onde: 137 tu ricca, tu con pace e tu con senno! 138 S’io dico ’l ver, l’effetto nol nasconde.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Now be joyful, for you have good reason: 137 you are rich, you have peace, and you have wisdom! 138 If I speak the truth, the effect does not hide it.
**Cornish:**
136 Mes lemmyn bos lowen, rag yth yw reson da: 137 ty yw koweth, ty yw gans peth ha gans sens! 138 Mar leverys an gwir, an effeyth na'n kevr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Atene e Lacedemona, che fenno 140 l’antiche leggi e furon sì civili, 141 fecero al viver bene un picciol cenno
142 verso di te, che fai tanto sottili 143 provedimenti, ch’a mezzo novembre 144 non giugne quel che tu d’ottobre fili.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Athens and Lacedaemon, which made 140 the ancient laws and were so civilized, 141 made only a small contribution to the good life
142 compared to you, who make such subtle 143 provisions that what you spin in October 144 does not reach completion until mid-November.
**Cornish:**
139 Athen ha Lakedaemon, a wruk 140 an hen lejyow ha veu kledhys, 141 a wruk nebes byghan dhe'n vyw bos
142 owth kompare dhe'gas, ty a wra 143 provysions kledh, dhe bys dhe'n hanter mis Du 144 na wra'n gorfenna an pyth a wra's ow spynna yn mis Hedra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 Quante volte, del tempo che rimembre, 146 legge, moneta, officio e costume 147 hai tu mutato, e rinovate membre!
148 E se ben ti ricordi e vedi lume, 149 vedrai te somigliante a quella inferma 150 che non può trovar posa in su le piume,
151 ma con dar volta suo dolore scherma.
query.result:
**English:**
145 How many times, in the time that I remember, 146 have you changed laws, currency, officials, and customs, 147 and renewed your members!
148 And if you remember well and see clearly, 149 you will see that you are like that sick woman 150 who cannot find rest on her bed,
151 but tries to relieve her pain by tossing and turning.
**Cornish:**
145 Pyth yw lies an termyn a'm kov, 146 lejyow, moneth, offis ha kostom 147 a wra's chanjys ha membrow nowydh!
148 Ha mar kov bos ha gweles golow, 149 gweles bos te dhevel dhe'n kledhes ma 150 na wra'n kavos pos yn-dann an pluv,
151 mes gans trohevel owth a wra'n owth dolour ow skerm.
